metadata.title: 5 Things To Know: July 16, 2025
metadata.description:
CNBC’s Andrew Ross Sorkin reports on the 5 things to know on July 16, 2025. For access to live and exclusive video from CNBC subscribe to CNBC PRO: https://cnb.cx/42d859g

» Subscribe to CNBC TV: https://cnb.cx/SubscribeCNBCtelevision
» Subscribe to CNBC: https://cnb.cx/SubscribeCNBC
» Watch CNBC on the go with CNBC+: https://www.cnbc.com/WatchCNBCPlus

Turn to CNBC TV for the latest stock market news and analysis. From market futures to live price updates CNBC is the leader in business news worldwide.

transcript.full_text: Welcome back to Squawk Box, five things to know ahead of today's opening bell. A source telling CNBC two federal investigations into online prediction betting site Polymarket have been closed with no charges filed against the company. The Justice Department and CFTC had been investigating whether Polymarket was accepting bets from people in the United States. Meanwhile, Republicans narrowly voting to advance a package of spending cuts proposed by President Trump. The procedural vote on that roughly $9 billion dollar package passed the Senate 51 to 50 with Vice President J.D. Vance breaking that tie. The measure seeks to claw back previously approved funding for foreign aid and the Corporation for Public Broadcasting with which funds PBS and NPR. And Elon Musk's company SpaceX planning an insider share sale that would value the company at roughly $400 billion. That's according to a Bloomberg report. And Tesla's top sales executive in North America has left the company. The Wall Street Journal reporting that Troy Jones, the company's vice president of sales, services delivery in the region, departing the company this after 15 years. He's the latest in a string of top executives to leave the company since April. And finally, a robot taking center stage in last night's Major League Baseball All-Star game, the ABS automated ball strike system coming into play in the first inning when catcher Cal Raleigh used it to challenge a call. He was right and it led to a strikeout. As CNBC's Alex Sherman reported yesterday, MLB Commissioner Rob uh Manfred supporting that new technology and it may be ready for every game next year. I'm all in favor of it. Instant replay, right? Instant replay. But then what was the thing that happened at Wimbledon this year where this AI system totally missed the call and then they didn't have a replay and who was it who lost the point and it like lost the whole match because of it. It was crazy. Oh. Umpires are I mean, tough job. Tough job. But I I've had, you know, now that I have sometimes I have some thing, you know, $5 or $10 on the line. There are times in an inning where one call if it's just egregious and totally obvious that it was bad. It's like that totally changed. It it hurts a rally or or it stops, you know, it can make a a difference. But then there's times when you need the the umpire instead of a machine. I I why? Why do you need the umpire? I'm trying to figure that out. Exactly because if the machine absolutely no, that's wrong. Like. Oh, the machine's wrong. That's bad. Obviously. I don't I don't know how I feel about that. Uh,

analysis.summary:
The broadcast opens with a segment on five key updates, starting with the news that two federal investigations into the online prediction betting platform, Polymarket, conducted by the Justice Department and the CFTC, have been closed without any charges filed. These investigations primarily focused on whether Polymarket was accepting wagers from individuals within the United States. Following this, the report shifts to political developments, detailing how Republicans narrowly succeeded in advancing a $9 billion package of spending cuts. This procedural vote passed the Senate by a slim 51-50 margin, with Vice President J.D. Vance casting the decisive tie-breaking vote. The proposed measure aims to claw back previously approved funds allocated for foreign aid and for the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, which is responsible for funding public media outlets like PBS and NPR.

In corporate news, SpaceX, led by Elon Musk, is reportedly planning an insider share sale. This sale is expected to value the aerospace company at an estimated $400 billion, according to a Bloomberg report. Concurrently, Tesla has experienced another high-level executive departure, with Troy Jones, the Vice President of Sales, Services Delivery in North America, leaving the company after 15 years. This exit, reported by The Wall Street Journal, marks Troy Jones as the latest in a series of top executives to depart Tesla since April, indicating a trend of leadership changes within the electric vehicle manufacturer.

The broadcast concludes with a discussion on the integration of technology in sports, specifically highlighting the use of the ABS automated ball strike system during the recent Major League Baseball All-Star game. During the first inning, catcher Cal Raleigh utilized the system to successfully challenge a call, which ultimately led to a strikeout. CNBC's Alex Sherman reported yesterday that MLB Commissioner Rob Manfred supports this new technology, suggesting it could be implemented across all MLB games as early as next year. The segment then transitions into a broader debate among the hosts about the merits and drawbacks of automated officiating versus human umpires, citing a controversial incident at Wimbledon this year where an AI system's error significantly impacted a match.

key_points.text: Introduction to Squawk Box's 'five things to know' segment.
Report on two federal investigations into online prediction betting site Polymarket.
Investigations, conducted by Justice Department and CFTC, have been closed.
No charges were filed against Polymarket following the federal investigations.
Justice Department and CFTC investigated if Polymarket accepted bets from US individuals.
Republicans narrowly voted to advance a package of spending cuts.
The spending cuts package was proposed by President Trump.
A procedural vote on the roughly $9 billion package passed the Senate.
The Senate vote on the package was 51 to 50.
Vice President J.D. Vance broke the tie vote in the Senate.
The measure seeks to claw back previously approved funding.
Claw back efforts target funding for foreign aid.
Claw back efforts also target funding for the Corporation for Public Broadcasting.
The Corporation for Public Broadcasting funds PBS.
The Corporation for Public Broadcasting funds NPR.
Elon Musk's company, SpaceX, is planning an insider share sale.
The share sale would value SpaceX at approximately $400 billion.
The valuation information for SpaceX comes from a Bloomberg report.
Tesla's top sales executive in North America has left the company.
The departing executive is Troy Jones.
Troy Jones was Tesla's Vice President of Sales, Services Delivery in North America.
Troy Jones departed Tesla after 15 years with the company.
The Wall Street Journal reported on Troy Jones' departure.
Troy Jones is the latest in a string of top executives to leave Tesla.
Executive departures from Tesla have been occurring since April.
A robot, the ABS automated ball strike system, was used in last night's Major League Baseball All-Star game.
The ABS system came into play in the first inning of the game.
Catcher Cal Raleigh used the ABS system to challenge a call.
Cal Raleigh's challenge using the ABS system was correct.
The successful challenge by Cal Raleigh led to a strikeout.
CNBC's Alex Sherman reported yesterday on MLB Commissioner Rob Manfred's support for the new technology.
MLB Commissioner Rob Manfred supports the ABS automated ball strike system.
The ABS technology may be ready for every MLB game next year.
A discussion about the general benefits of instant replay in sports.
An incident at Wimbledon this year involving an AI system missing a call was mentioned.
The AI system at Wimbledon reportedly missed a call, and there was no replay available.
The missed AI call at Wimbledon led to a player losing a point and potentially the whole match.
The hosts acknowledge that umpires have a tough job.
Discussion on how one egregious or obvious bad call can significantly impact a game.
A bad call can hurt a rally or make a crucial difference in an inning.
A debate arises on situations where a human umpire might be preferred over a machine.
A question is posed regarding the necessity of a human umpire if a machine is absolutely accurate.
Consideration of potential issues if the automated machine itself is wrong.

timeline_events.event_description: Two federal investigations into online prediction betting site Polymarket were closed with no charges filed against the company.
Republicans narrowly voted to advance a package of spending cuts proposed by President Trump.
Elon Musk's company SpaceX is planning an insider share sale, valuing the company at roughly $400 billion.
Troy Jones, Tesla's Vice President of Sales, Services Delivery in North America, left the company after 15 years.
A robot (ABS automated ball-strike system) was used in the first inning of the Major League Baseball All-Star game, where catcher Cal Raleigh used it to successfully challenge a call.
CNBC's Alex Sherman reported that MLB Commissioner Rob Manfred supports the new ABS technology.
The ABS automated ball-strike system may be ready for every Major League Baseball game.
An AI system at Wimbledon reportedly missed a crucial call, leading to a player losing a point and potentially the match.

temporal_patterns.description: A recurring pattern of top executives, including Troy Jones, leaving Tesla, indicating ongoing changes or challenges within the company.
temporal_patterns.significance: Highlights a period of significant personnel changes within Tesla, potentially reflecting internal shifts or external pressures.
temporal_patterns.timespan: Since April (of the current year) to present

temporal_patterns.description: The progression of the ABS automated ball-strike system's adoption in Major League Baseball, from its experimental use in the All-Star game to potential widespread implementation in future seasons.
temporal_patterns.significance: Illustrates the typical adoption curve for new technology in professional sports, moving from testing to broader application.
temporal_patterns.timespan: From 'last night' (All-Star game) to 'next year' (potential full rollout)

temporal_patterns.description: An ongoing debate regarding the reliability and necessity of human umpires versus automated (AI) systems in sports officiating, exemplified by the Wimbledon AI system's missed call.
temporal_patterns.significance: Reflects the continuous tension and discussion surrounding technological advancement and human judgment in traditional sports.

robot taking center stage in last night's Major League Baseball All-Star game
As CNBC's Alex Sherman reported yesterday
it may be ready for every game next year
